senses.de: A sequence of railroad cars moved as a unit by a locomotive or by integral motors
senses.ex: He took a train from New York to Chicago

Tips.title: Transport Context
Tips.description: Used when discussing travel by rail or the vehicles themselves.

Tips.title: Station Vocabulary
Tips.description: Train is associated with specific terms like 'station', 'platform', and 'track'.
Tips.example: Meet me at the train station.

Tips.title: Schedule Importance
Tips.description: Trains often run on a tight schedule, punctuality is key.
Tips.example: The train leaves sharp at 6 PM.

senses.de: Teach or refine to be discriminative in taste or judgment
senses.ex: She is training to be a teacher

Tips.title: Skill Development
Tips.description: Refers to practicing a skill or studying.

Tips.title: Professional Preparation
Tips.description: Often refers to formal education or job preparations.
Tips.example: I'm training to become a pilot.

Tips.title: Routine Emphasis
Tips.description: Training usually involves a consistent, regular routine or program.
Tips.example: Her training schedule is very strict.

senses.ex: He trained his binoculars on the bird

Tips.title: Focus Precision
Tips.description: To direct attentively towards a specific object or target.
Tips.example: The hunter trained his rifle on the deer.

Tips.title: Careful Aim
Tips.description: Involves careful positioning to ensure accuracy.
Tips.example: He trained the spotlight on the sign.

senses.de: A procession (of wagons or mules or camels) traveling together in single file
senses.ex: We were part of a caravan train for security purposes

Tips.title: Group Movement
Tips.description: Used historically to describe a line of travelers or vehicles moving together.
Tips.example: The camel train crossed the desert.

Tips.title: Security Implication
Tips.description: Implies safety in numbers during travel, commonly in historical texts.
Tips.example: The trade train was guarded by soldiers.

senses.de: A long piece of fabric attached to the back of a formal dress or robe that spreads out behind the wearer
senses.ex: Her wedding dress had a long train

Tips.title: Ceremonial Elegance
Tips.description: Describes the formal and graceful aspect of long attire, often seen in weddings.
Tips.example: The bride's train was adorned with lace.

Tips.title: Fashion Statement
Tips.description: Often associated with fashion and formality.
Tips.example: The actor wore a gown with an elegant train.

Caboose.wordDefinition:
A caboose is a small car attached to the end of a freight train, traditionally used as a shelter for the train crew.

A train is applicable in transportation of goods or people, while a caboose is typically used in a freight train to provide a shelter for the crew at the end of the train.

However, nowadays, many new train models have developed and caboose has become less common.

Carriage.wordDefinition:
A carriage is a part of a train that carries passengers or goods. It is an individual compartment or car that is connected to other carriages to form a train.

Train is a term used to describe the entire transportation system, including the locomotive, carriages, tracks, and stations.

A carriage is a smaller part of a train that carries passengers or goods, while a train refers to the entire system of transportation.

People would use the word carriage when referring to the specific area of the train where they are seated or where their luggage is stored.

Coach.wordDefinition:
The words coach and train both refer to helping someone improve in a certain area, but they are used in different ways.

Coach usually refers to a person who helps guide and support someone in achieving their goals. For example, a sports coach helps players improve their skills and achieve their best on the field.

A life coach helps people improve their overall well-being and achieve their personal and professional goals.

So, in short, a coach helps guide and support someone in achieving their goals, while a train teaches and practices a specific skill or behavior.

Engine.wordDefinition:
An engine is a machine used for power generation or production of mechanical energy, while a train is a group of connected vehicles or carriages that are pulled or pushed by a locomotive engine.

The term engine is used more broadly and can refer to any machine that converts energy into mechanical power, such as a car engine or a generator.

The term train is specifically used for a group of interconnected carriages or wagons that are attached to an engine or locomotive and is used for transportation of people or goods.

So, while an engine can be used for various purposes like power generation, transportation, or production of mechanical energy, a train refers only to a vehicle that is meant for transportation of people or goods and is invariably pulled or pushed by an engine.

Express.wordDefinition:
In general, both words express and train refer to a mode of transportation that operates on a fixed schedule and follows a designated route to transport passengers from one place to another.

An express train usually refers to a faster and more limited-stop train service that passes fewer stations than a local or regional train.

Express trains typically make stops only at major cities or important destinations along their route, so they are faster but may have fewer stops along the way.

A train can refer to any type of railway service – including express trains, but also local, regional, or commuter trains that make several stops along their route.

Express is specifically used when referring to a fast, non-stop train service, while the word train can have a broader meaning that includes express services as well as any other type of railway service.

Locomotive.wordDefinition:
A locomotive is the engine that pulls the train, while a train is a collection of railroad cars that are connected to each other and are pulled by a locomotive.

The locomotive provides the power to move the train along tracks. To understand it better, think of a car and a car's engine.

The car is like the train, and the engine is like the locomotive. The engine powers the car and makes it move.

Similarly, the locomotive powers the train and makes it move.

Railroad.wordDefinition:
Railroad refers to the infrastructure, tracks, and systems used for transportation on rails. This includes things like the rails themselves, the stations, and the maintenance equipment.

Train refers to the specific vehicles that run on the railroad tracks and transport people or cargo from one place to another.

In simpler terms, the railroad is the pathway for trains to travel on, while the train is the vehicle that travels on the railroad.

Wagon.wordDefinition:
Wagon is a four-wheeled vehicle used for transporting goods on land.

Wagons can be pulled by animals or vehicles and are usually used for short distances.

In short, trains are larger and used for long-distance travel while wagons are smaller and used for shorter distances.

quotes.Text: You must respect people and work hard to be in shape. And I used to train very hard. When the others players went to the beach after training, I was there kicking the ball.
quotes.Title: Brazilian Athlete
quotes.Name: Pele

quotes.Text: Your job as an actor is to piece together whatever you've learned in your training, or whatever you have experienced in your life, to piece together a person.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Viola Davis

quotes.Text: Neither a wise man nor a brave man lies down on the tracks of history to wait for the train of the future to run over him.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Dwight D. Eisenhower

quotes.Text: An individual step in character training is to put responsibility on the individual.
quotes.Title: English Soldier
quotes.Name: Robert Baden-Powell

quotes.Text: I spent my whole life playing sports and training and pushing myself to the limits.
quotes.Title: American Tennis Player
quotes.Name: Venus Williams

quotes.Text: Footballers from the street are more important than trained coaches.
quotes.Title: Dutch Athlete
quotes.Name: Johan Cruyff

quotes.Text: I'm training once a day, four days a week, and just loving life.
quotes.Title: English Athlete
quotes.Name: Katarina Johnson-Thompson

quotes.Text: I train mainly with guys, and they help to push me.
quotes.Title: Ethiopian Athlete
quotes.Name: Genzebe Dibaba

quotes.Text: I train with the best coaches in the world.
quotes.Title: Polish Athlete
quotes.Name: Joanna Jedrzejczyk
